verses.text: Praise the LORD. Praise the LORD from the heavens, praise him in the heights above.
Praise him, all his angels, praise him, all his heavenly hosts.
Praise him, sun and moon, praise him, all you shining stars.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 148
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 148 The summons to praise takes prominence over the reasons for praise in this psalm. The initial exhortation is toward heaven (vv. 1–6), the second to the earth (vv. 7–12), and the last to the chosen people of God (vv. 13, 14).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 148:1
rsbNotes.text: 148:1 the heavens. The heavens are normally described as containing different levels, though the details are never spelled out in the Bible (cf. 2 Cor. 12:2). The highest heavens cannot contain God (1 Kin. 8:27), showing that His transcendence cannot be measured.

verses.text: Praise him, you highest heavens and you waters above the skies.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 148:4
rsbNotes.text: 148:4 waters above the heavens. See Gen. 1:7.

verses.text: Let them praise the name of the LORD, for he commanded and they were created.
He set them in place for ever and ever; he gave a decree that will never pass away.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 148:5
rsbNotes.text: 148:5 they were created. See the six days of creation in Gen. 1; theological note “God the Creator” on next page.

verses.text: Praise the LORD from the earth, you great sea creatures and all ocean depths,
lightning and hail, snow and clouds, stormy winds that do his bidding,
you mountains and all hills, fruit trees and all cedars,
wild animals and all cattle, small creatures and flying birds,

rsbNotes.title: Ps 148:7
rsbNotes.text:
148:7 from the earth. This idea is elaborated in the following verses as different parts of creation are called to praise God.

sea creatures. The sea was a source of special fascination and fear to the Israelites. Often, the sea represents everything opposed to God and His created order (18:4, 15 notes). God’s greatness is demonstrated as He requires their praise.

verses.text: kings of the earth and all nations, you princes and all rulers on earth,
young men and maidens, old men and children.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 148:11
rsbNotes.text: 148:11 Kings of the earth. The psalm proclaims that universal praise is due to the Lord (138:4 note).

verses.text: Let them praise the name of the LORD, for his name alone is exalted; his splendor is above the earth and the heavens.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 148:13
rsbNotes.text: 148:13 the name of the Lord. See Ps. 8:1.

verses.text: He has raised up for his people a horn, the praise of all his saints, of Israel, the people close to his heart. Praise the LORD.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 148:14
rsbNotes.text:
148:14 a horn. The horn symbolizes the strength and vigor of the nation as a whole or the king in particular. See 92:10 note.

near to him. See Deut. 7:7–11.
